job_title: Patient Care Technician in New York, NY
pros: Here's my honest opinion...I've worked in the UES location for almost 4 years. I love the location and the people I work with. My manager is great and she is fair. She always pushes you to do better and cares. Because of her I was able to return to school and pursue my degree. The tuition reimbursement is great, the benefits are phenomenal, the 401k plan is pretty good too. The overtime is unlimited when there is a need. I've worked at both Koch and the main campus and all I can say is that the people here are good and they care. Even under stressful situations we usually come together and make things work. I truly can't see myself working anywhere else. I love providing quality care to my patients because that's what they deserve. When patients come here they know that they are in good hands. We all make sure of it. I am so fortunate to be here.
cons: None that I can think of....This is a great place to work for and yes people have left to go to other hospitals, thinking the grass would be greener on the other side. One thing I will say is that no hospital in NYC tops Memorial Sloan Kettering, so when people leave they eventually come back because of the family dynamic we have here.

review_title: Amazing people, but needs to work on retention
job_title: Budget Associate in New York, NY
pros: Starting pay tends to be more competitive than other New York City hospitals. Great health insurance, generous $12K tuition reimbursement, and good 401k match plan. Some jobs have remote flexibility. Fantastic mission and very smart people to work with.
cons: Pay increases aren't performance-based unless your manager really goes to bat for you. You'll likely get a standard cost of living raise every year. I also never received any type of bonus for "exceeding expectations". While there is a good process in place for employees to apply to internal positions, salary for these internal transfers are not handled appropriately. Rather than getting paid the appropriate value of the new role, HR tends to base your new compensation as a percentage increase (usually no more than 10%) of your current role.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros: MSK has great benefits. They have 20 days of vacation and great healthcare benefits as well. You can work a hybrid schedule, 2 or 3 days are onsite depending on your role. You can gain a lot of great experience and work on interesting projects if you make the effort to connect with people across the organization. Upward mobility is possible if you are friendly with the right people.
cons: If you are good at your job, you will be asked to do the work of 2-3 people without any extra pay. Lower level employees are eligible for bonuses if they work on special projects or take on extra work, but they don't tell you that you are. Raises are very small, even if you get a promotion, the raise will usually be 3% or less. Lower level employees are eligible for bonuses if they work on special projects or take on extra work, but they don't tell you that you are.

review_title: Run far far far away from this role
job_title: Office Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Advertised as entry level and will hire college grad with no experience. Benefits - tuition reimbursements.
cons: **This is specifically for department of surgery at MSKCC*** It will be your downfall if you have zero healthcare experience. No room for mistakes/errors/growth. Someone I trained was fired 3 days shy of completing her 6 months probation. Whatever you do if you apply for this position - stay FAR AWAY from the dept of surgery, go to medicine. A job that can be done 100% remote but insist and require staff to sit in cubicle 3 days onsite (not patient + rarely see your MDs and clinical team). Zero flexibility with that, would rather have you call out than let you work remotely to keep the office staffed and not having other OCs covering 2-3 MD offices. TOXIC work culture, passive aggressive upper management. Management will immediately throw staff under bus. If a doctor unprofessionally yells at you and it was escalated to management… management laughs it off and doesn’t do anything about it. Lots of hyper fixation on mistakes, mass influx of anxiety, etc. Blackout dates for taking time off, your PTO will be rejected if your coverage partners can’t cover. For your mental health DO NOT WORK AS AN OC.

review_title: Overall Review- the bad and the ugly Revenue Cycle Optimization (RCO) Team
job_title: Financial Analyst in New York, NY
pros: The main and only pro for the job is that you will be remote. However that comes with no stipend for WFH setup costs. To the managers who are willing to work alongside growing analyst are incredibly helpful. However, if that work is outside your direct manager it is very likely your efforts will not be heard.
cons: Management is by far the worst I have experienced in years with little to no guidance on expectations and roll responsibilities. My direct manager was rarely open for questions and when my questions were received they were used against me as bait for poor performance - "inability to work without direct information." With no information and only an end goal in the harsh political environment of the company how does one expect a decent job. For any analyst, expect to go out of your way for information in-order to go around your boss as analysts aren't expected to utilize the direct managers. The mind set of the team is figure it out yourself or you'll look bad but senior analyst and managers are not willing to help in the process. To that point, it is not a job for free thinking and growth oriented analyst. Look somewhere else for a job. Lastly, the company terrible financial performance is hidden by the gross amount of direct free funding from the government. You'll have no pay increase during your time and no bonuses. The expected time from analyst to analyst 2 is 3 years. There are 4 levels of analyst till you get to senior analyst. At that rate you'll be ~35 till you can make >100,000. GL

review_title: Good pay, benefits, and people but poor management & lack of support
job_title: Clinical Research Associate in New York, NY
pros: Research here is top notch - so many different trials, departments and people you will get to work with as well as various platforms. Great place to learn more and develop your skills if you are interested in clinical research. Compared to other hospitals, MSK pays very well.
cons: While the pay is good, expect to be working overtime and expect to feel guilty for your other colleagues when you take off from work. The position is very demanding as you'll be responsible for many patients and their care under research (think of patient's appointments, enrollment on trial, their treatment and compliance). Along with that, you'll also be primary contact for the protocols you are assigned to and required to meet the demands of the investigators and leadership. The work volume can definitely be overwhelming, especially if your department is disorganized and/or if your managers do not provide you support which I found in my case.

job_title: Office Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Depending on your clinical team, you can work with some of the most amazing doctors and nurses. Patients can be wonderful to speak to and you feel fulfilled when helping them coordinate their care. The benefits are great as well!
cons: Beware management (depending on your department). It is clear management does not care about their employees. They will drive away their best employees by rewarding good work with more work. They rather have a few good employees pick up the slack, rather than re-train/replace lazy staff. It is common to be in double coverage for several months at a time, and when you ask for an incentive, don't expect to hear back. Expect to work several hours of overtime, and don't expect to feel appreciated when you go above and beyond. Office coordinators should be compensated much more than they currently are.

review_title: Hesitated posting this, but... people should know.
job_title: Senior Research Scientist in New York, NY
pros: Good research being performed, a lot of access to state-of-the-art equipment which is not available at institutions with less money. Looks good on your resume. People are always impressed you worked there.
cons: Salary - $82,000 a year. Enough to live in NYC, but you cant enjoy living in NYC. Most of your salary goes to mandatory expenses like rent, utilities, and public transit. Postdocs have access to subsidized housing, but it's still hard to make ends meet. This causes stress and makes you come to work tired or with a bad attitude because you cant enjoy yourself outside of work. Work-life Balance - non-existent. As a researcher, I was expected to work and answer emails while on vacation. This expectation was not expressed to me during the interview process at all. All while giving 110% and working more than 7.5 hours a day and weekends. I would expect that the 2 weeks a year I have to myself I truly had to myself. Management/Senior Management - they are researchers who were promoted and do not have good empathy or people skills. It's all about the bottom line to them. I was treated like a commodity that had to produce continuously, even when exceeding the productivity of the previous year.

cons: Very poor, unprofessional management. The assistant managers of medical oncology and radiology make the work environment very hostile with the way they treat the staff they oversee. The conversations and the way they speak to the office coordinators and care coordinators is very inappropriate. Staff is completely overworked and underpaid and you are "counseled" if you try to work overtime and questioned why your work isn't completed before your shift has ended. The staff is a constant rotating door and although many staff members have filed complaints about management, HR rarely gets involved to help investigate and or rectify issues that are arising. This will continue to be an issue until HR steps in to see why staff keep resigning from their positions to work at other local healthcare institutions

review_title: An honest rant about the labor/maintenance/technical departments
job_title: Radiation Safety Technician in Manhattan, KS
pros: Clean, friendly staff, close to bus/subway
cons: Being stuck in between your bosses and management, and the people you see and work with everyday, you don't want to outwork them because they'll feel threatened, but you also don't want to slack off because then you'll be called to the office about your job performance. This went on in many departments not only mine but I had a first-hand experience of being let go for trying to get along with everybody and do things the way they've always been done by the current employees, I was even called in for a pre-hire run by my boss to see if my future co-workers would "like" and "be okay" with me being hired, which greatly warped my view on who to listen to when things needed to be done. Of course upper management wants as much done as efficiently as possible, but my fellow coworkers didn't want to do things that they didn't have to do all at once, they like to spread their work out so they could stay busy, in my case I like to finish all my duties within the first 2 hours in the morning so by midday I was sweeping my office for the next 4 hours straight because I had nothing to do and it looked like I was just lazy sitting in the office doing nothing. I would intentionally let stuff I knew could get backed up, back up a bit so I could have a full day, but my boss saw that as a mess in me not doing my duties but when I did too much there was nothing for me to do and I would get the talk by my coworkers to not work too hard because then they'll always expect it. It was just a bad situation for me and it seems like everybody that winds up leaving there has a similar story. I have nothing against the people that work there, I just wish people were more honest with what they wanted and assured you that if you do the job the way I want you to do it you'll never have to worry about your job instead of me worrying if I work too hard my coworkers will hate me and plot against me but if I work too little upper management will get rid of me, they gave me crazy anxiety.

review_title: Great colleagues, not enough room for growth
job_title: Care Coordinator II in New York, NY
pros:
I've never worked somewhere with nicer individuals. I truly met some of my best friends to this day because everyone who works here is naturally empathetic and compassionate. On the administrative team, everyone supports each other and it is not uncommon for a colleague to quietly pick up extra work to assist another struggling team member. This was my first job out of college so I found this culture to be incredibly helpful. They also train you incredibly thoroughly so that by the time you are on your own you feel very confident which I appreciated. 
A lot of opportunity for overtime
Many sites offer a 4-day work week
TUITION REIMBURSEMENT!!
cons:
Growth opportunities are incredibly limited. I postponed a promotion to interview for a job in a different department (same job but different specialty) and I went through three interviews and then 5 months of radio silence only to be told they were going with an outside hire. When I asked the team that interviewed me for feedback they did not respond and I never was given any clarity on how to improve my chances so I didn't apply again.
Also during my 3+ years at the institution, we were consistently short-staffed which definitely contributed to a lot of burnout on the staff.
It is very common to be asked to stay multiple hours past your shift with little to no notice.

job_title: Anonymous in New York, NY
pros: It’s a good place to work ! Nice pay and benefits however things are getting a bit more difficult now
cons:
The new CFO seems to hire people without looking for talent in the organization to promote . There are so many talented directors but many powerful positions are being filled by outsiders. We used to have a great grievance mechanism to express our issues but now we have nothing of that sort. It just exists as a namesake with no real actionable powers.

 There is a general sense of feeling among the employees in our department that they are just told about a decision that was made by the newcomers and we have to live with it and have no say whatsoever. A simple task that took a few hours to do is now taking days because no one really cares and have given up and just doing the bare minimum to get by.

There was a CDO that was hired in information technology sometime ago and he started several initiatives but conveniently left the organization in a short time and letting everything descend in to chaos. Somehow there is an eerie similarity to what we are going through as well.

review_title: An Inspiring and Highly Rewarding Place to Work

I am deeply inspired to work on all kinds of projects, my experience and voice is trusted and encouraged, and there are seriously skilled people here from whom I'm always learning--and I'm no digital communications novice. The compensation and benefits package is extremely competitive and overall work environment encourages trust, learning, mutual respect, and collaborative improvement.
cons: The institution is growing by leaps and bounds in its outlook toward the future and in preparing for the research, patient care, marketing, and clinical challenges that lie ahead--a great thing--but there could be a tad bit more attention given to improving and/or standardizing workflows and processes. Luckily, this is a highly solvable issue, and the right people and personalities are increasingly being put in place to streamline efforts.

job_title: Senior Software Developer in London, England
pros:
Technology at MSK is in the midst of a digital transformation, with entirely new management, bringing needed organization and focus. For some, that can be jarring, and for some, it can be an opportunity, the latter more for new hires on new projects.

Also, painted as a positive - it remains to be seen - is that there are no longer people-only managers, recently instituting a system where technology skills can be appreciated and can continue to rise in pay and rank, rather than having only people-managers rising.

As an organization, it is committed to diversity and is openly supportive, fostering discussion groups with senior management. It is also a heavily female organization, with women in senior IT roles, as well as across the organization.

Likely, as a medical institution, education and certification are appreciated and paid for, and depending on where you work, access to Pluralsight, LinkedIn Learning, and classes, both internal and external.
cons:
Advancement can be hard, both because there are many long-time employees, but also that managers are often hired externally, particularly now, with a new CTO bringing in his teams, and his hires bringing with them former coworkers.

A recent change has been a new evaluation system, so that performance that is considered by one's managers exceptional, and where someone might produce innovative products, as well as outscore/out-skill the majority of peers in one's industry, is rated as merely satisfactory.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros: MSK offers excellent benefits, especially 401k. New hire training was two days. I met some really wonderful people from every part of the organization. My mother was a patient many years ago, and I really wanted to work there. Some of the Lead Admins I met were also wonderful and available to help.
cons:
I have many years of experience and have worked with high-level people but MSK was very challenging and one of the most difficult. Researchers are gifted, but that doesn't translate into being a good boss. I experienced rudeness and poor communication skills. The backhanded behavior was most disappointing.  You can't transfer to another position until you've been employed for a year (I tried). My experience was untenable. 

While interviewing, do your research and engage everyone as much as possible. Ask questions. You will be required to hit the ground running, possibly with little guidance. If you have previous experience at a hospital you will figure it out. If you don't, beware. Benefits are great but salary was low and non-negotiable at hiring.

job_title: Care Coordinator in New York, NY
pros:
- This hospital really does do anything & everything to keep it's patient's in the best care.
- Employee Benefits are undeniably decent.
- The weight of having this hospital on your resume is significant, if you have healthcare aspirations.
cons:
- This hospital's concern for patients is fueled by an intense fear to lose money or be exposed for how unorganized things are.
- In order for management to elevate, they must push who they manage to the limit and be willing to fire or threaten their job without being given the ability to properly assist them by higher management.
- Nepotism is at an all time high. I know this is usual for most companies, but it's very intense here as are all other -isms you can imagine.
- Company does everything it can to avoid paying retirement to employees. 
- Company doesn't change based on needs of employees, but only based on needs of patients or people who will be donating money.
- Medical provider's use employment to up there loved ones' treatment quality no matter how it affects other patient's care.
- Hospital Management cannot control Doctors resulting in huge power imbalance.
- Extremely high turnover rate which every department refuses to be accountable for or investigate.

job_title: Registered Nurse in New York, NY
pros: I've worked at 4 different hospitals around the country and this hospital has by far the most support services for nurses that I've seen, including an IV team, admissions nurse, discharge nurse, and resource nurse. All of the staff from RNs to transport, to environmental services seems to really like working there (comparative to other places). The relationship with patients and staff is unique because most of our patients we see recurring throughout the years. Also, no floating! The pay is also a major plus, best salary I've ever had with a lot of room to grow with their tiered promotion scale.
cons: Since it's such a specific patient population it's very different from other hospitals and therefore it feels almost like working in a bubble from the rest of the medical field. The policies and equipment seem out of date because it takes so so long for new policies or procedures to be approved. Their EMAR system isn't great, they don't use EPIC. The staff is cliquey, mainly because for the most part they try to only hire friends of current employees (at least within nursing). The nursing staff for the most part it very young and inexperienced. They're good nurses for the specific type of cancer they trained on just overall inexperienced. Each floor is a different cancer and since they don't float it's unlikely they will get experience in anything that doesn't pertain their "their patients". They mainly only hire new grads so they are easy to mold but this means that they are extremely set in their ways. As a former traveler I found it hard to assimilate and after 2.5 years I still seem to have trouble as they are so different from every other hospital. It's also all cancer which means a lot of death or watching people get treatment well past their time so be prepared.

cons: Management micromanages to the point of making you feel like you are back in high school! job_title: Clinical Dietitian in New York, NY
pros: High quality MDs and RNs with magnet status; numerous internal lectures, grand rounds, nutrition conference to attend as time permits; growing opportunities as more satellite centers open (one dietitian hired per center); more resources than other institutions (e.g.we develop & publish our own patient education materials, have our own medical library, patients have a recreation area where they can do crafts and attend special events etc.). Clinical dietitian ladders recently approved, so there is some opportunity for growth, but too early to offer a judgment as to its success.  Overall a great place to work, despite caveats below.
cons: Census always seems to be over capacity and patient acuity has risen with shift to outpatient centers for treatment & less complex surgeries, so it can get very busy/stressful & difficult to keep up with new admissions & follow-up of existing patients.  Dietitians are unit-based & don't get a chance to change assignments unless someone leaves, so work can get repetitious (unless you are in a relief position, where your floor assignment is constantly changing) as the floors are arranged by service/diagnosis, although there are many that prefer to remain on their same floor.  The dietitians cover all patients except for those on TPN, they are followed by GI/Nutrition MDs & NPs. Difficult to find affordable housing in Manhattan at dietitian level salary (& dietitians not eligible for more affordable hospital housing), therefore, many dietitians commute from outer boroughs, Westchester or New Jersey & commuting to NYC is not fun.  When I started the benefits were great & the salary was low.  Now the salary is competitive, but budgets seem to get tighter every year & health insurance keeps getting more expensive, but those are universal issues.

review_title: I love working here, despite flaws
job_title: Research Project Manager in New York, NY
pros:
-Excellent benefit package.
-Almost everyone there is there to do good and because they truly believe in the cause.
-Work/life balance in clinical research is fairly good. (Not good in other roles, but I cannot personally speak to that!)
-Leadership has begun reorganizing clinical research under one heading to streamline everything. This is THE BEST thing that's happened since we got electronic medical records.
-Tuition reimbursement up to $12,500/year.
cons:
-I work in clinical research, and traditionally it is an area filled with significant regulatory hurdles that the hospital seems to be content with letting each individual group handle, instead of deciding on one solution.
-A bit behind on technology, and many systems/databases don't talk to each other.
-Very difficult to get a raise without a corresponding promotion. Promotions are quite slow and require significant haggling at the managerial level to obtain. (Given it's a non-profit, I can understand some scarcity of funds, but MSK needs to stay competitive to prevent rapid turnover and attract high-quality management at every level.)
-There is favoritism afoot. If a higher-up likes you, prepare for promotions. If not, either figure out how to earn that favor or look elsewhere.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in New York, NY
pros:
-Great healthcare benefits
-Good paid vacation
-Reputable cancer center 
-Invaluable healthcare related experience
cons: Speaking from my personal experience working as a CRC in the Clinical Trials Office (ABMT), the large amount of work, the lack of guidance and training can make this job challenging. I unfortunately was assigned a very unhelpful and unfriendly supervisor and this greatly undermined my success in this company. A lot of the CRC's complain about how unhappy they are, the workload is high, there is little to no training when assigned protocols, but management expects you to know everything about the protocol. My supervisor whose role is suppose to be support and guidance, was very mean and unfriendly towards me and when I asked for guidance I was often met with a condescending attitude. What hurt me the most was that I proactively tried to address this issue with upper management on multiple occasions and this led to my termination with no explanation.
